title: 109_s1529
content:
The "City of Yuma Improvement Act" is the short title of the legislation. It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "City" referring to Yuma, Arizona, "Federal land" including specific parcels and locations, "Map" as the document dated July 25, 2005, "Non-federal land" as the "Railroad Parcels", and "Secretary" as the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 3. CONVEYANCE OF FEDERAL LAND AND NON-FEDERAL LAND. The Secretary will convey all US rights in Federal land to the City in exchange for non-Federal land. The City will receive fee simple title to the Federal land upon meeting specified requirements for the non-Federal land's title. The Secretary will convey all US rights in Federal land to the City in exchange for non-Federal land, including existing rights, easements, and rights-of-way. The non-Federal land acquired will be administered by the Secretary through the Commissioner of Reclamation. Upon conveyance of the Federal land to the City, the United States will be released from liability for damages, except for acts of negligence committed before the conveyance. The City will be responsible for all administrative costs related to the conveyance. The City will pay the United States for the land exchange. The value of Federal and non-Federal land will be equalized through appraisals conducted by an independent appraiser. Appraisals must adhere to specific standards for Federal land acquisition and professional appraisal practices. Equalization of values between Federal and non-Federal land will be done through independent appraisals to ensure equality in value for the land exchange. The Secretary may make a cash equalization payment to the City, or the City may make a payment to the Secretary, or the acreage of the land may be reduced. Any payments received by the Secretary will be deposited in the Treasury. The Secretary will convey US Fish and Wildlife Service land to the City in Yuma, Arizona. The City must pay fair market value for the land, cover administrative costs, and any proceeds will go to the Secretary. Amounts paid to the Secretary under subsection (b) will be used for administrative costs of the conveyance and constructing the Kofa National Wildlife Refuge headquarters and visitor center in Yuma, Arizona.
